div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. Steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:-

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia,
Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the
Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now
a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other anciest ruins and the Venetian fortification,
the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello" and of Ford's "lover's Melancholy."
The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the
General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248-31-12-907

div.head: SILENCE OF RUSSIA.
div.p:
It is vain to dogmatise on the signs of
revolution. With different nations revolution
will accomplish itself in different ways. In
France is seen a fiery, frantic outburt, pro-
ducing horrors that leave an indelible mark on
the imaginations of men, England changes the
ruling dyansty from Stuart to Hanover with
the calm matter-of-factness which it displays
in the ordinary affairs of life. Neither affords
any criterion from which to judge the prob-
abilities in Russia. Whether or not revvolut-
tion is brewing there, who shall decide. Only
he who possesses infallible knowledge of the
Russian character. And where shall such a
man be found?

Without pretending to find portent in St.
Petersburg, says the "Evening standard and
St. James's Gazette," we would draw attetion
to the strange state of feeling there. Assassina-
tion has followed assassination. The Terrorists
are said to have drawn up a list of prominent
adminstrators whom they have condemned to
death, and on that list are working with
deliberate determination. The first three
names have been crossed out. Theri owners
have fallen to the murderers revolver. The fourth name is that of Admiral Dubassoff,
whose fate yet hangs in the balance. now, this
list made or may not exit, but there is so firm a
belief in it that the threatened men have come
to regard themselves as actually doomed. The
City Perfect, having received a letter warning
him that he would be killed on such and such
a day, felt that his hour had come, and on the
fatal morning, says the "Telegraph" corres-
pondent with the authority of a member of
the family, when setting out for the inagura-
tion of the new church, he kissed his children with
unwanted tenderness and blessed them with
great fervour. General Pavloff, having reason
to think thathe was on the list, never ventured
out of his house on foot, aking exercise in a
little garden of a few square feet. Admiral
Dubassof declines to take these precautions.
He walks abroad as uaul, faicng danger in the
open -- perhaps in the Oriental faith, strength-
ened by the fate of Pavloff, that if death is to
come it will not be barred by walls and drawn
swords. The other day the report was spread
that he has been assassinated, and was
instantly accepted. Everybody is prepared for
it. Attention seems to have been diverted for the
oment from all others and to have concentraed on the Admiral.

An appaling state of things. This cold-
blooded advertisement of the next vistim, and
the public confidence that the sacrifice will be
made, strikes one as infinitely more horrible
than mob passion venting itself in tumult and
blood. The assassinations cause no surpise.
When they are reported the people accepted them
philopsophically. We fancy we hear them
mururing "kismet" and see them bowing
their heads not before the will of God but
before the will of the Terrorists. The idea
Fate has possesses them and the so called
guardians of order so completely that few
and feeble attempts are put forth to stay
the hand of the avenger. Openly threatned
as the Prefect was, the police took no effec-
tive precautions to defend him. The assasin
of Pavloff gained admittance to the house on
the flimsiest of pretexts to take a hotliday abroad. The
brave ones who remain adopt the attitude of
stories rather than that of strong men strug-
gling against adversity. All that is ventured
is to hand the murdered who has done his work,
and wait for an opportnity of handing the
next.

Ordinary, undistinguished, unthreatened,
people do not talk of the progress of the Terror
as they walk around the streets. It is not safe
to do so. For long it has not been safe to talk
in Russia. Yet we hear of the "notorous
sympathy of the public with the criminals".
We have besides that general statements that
atual words, declared to be characteristic of
the feeling of a great class, of the mother of
Ignsteiff's assassin -- a prosperious, educated
woman. "Don't think, darling," she said to
her son, "that I am going to reproach you.
On the contrary, I have nothing but priase for
your action. You behaved as a true Christian.
You have bibly laid down your life for your
racing through the streets tongues did begin
to wag. What they uttered was not horror of
the murder, but approbation of the murderer.

When things come to this pass in a great
city its superficial calm - that is to say, its
freedom from violent general upheaval such
as is suppored the precursor of revolution - is
no matter for congratulation but cause for
anxiety graver than than created by the
outbreaks of a few peasants ina re mote corner
of the land. It made be said that if St. Peters-
burg is ill disposed the rest of the country
will be hard to rouse. Revolutions, howvwer,
are often manufactured and carried through
in a capital, and the nation follows the capital,
raityfing its decision. Whether revolution
be brooding over St. Petersburg we cannot
satisfy ourselves, nor can anybody satisfy us.
But the silence of Russia - the terrible malig-
nant, mysterious silence - is more ominous
than the uprour of Bloody Sunday.

div.p:
The Khedive has approved and ratified the

tional Institute of Agriculture.

div.head: Fatal Camel Site.
div.p:
A few days ago, a native of Nahiet Sina-
nieh, Damietta, was attacked by a savage
camel, which seized hi by the teeth and
began to swing him to and gro, lashing him
against the ground until the poor man succumd-
ed to his injuries.

div.head: A Village Affray.
div.p:
Yesterday afternoon, an Aunstrian landowner
at Kafrel Sighar, near Kafra Zayat, had an
altercation with two feaalbeen, who eventually
attached him. The Austrian took his gun and
wounded one of them. An inquiry has been
opened by the Austrian consular authorities
at ALexandria.

div.head: Plague Dying Out.
div.p:
During the last week only three cases of
plague were reported, and no further case of
outbreak of the disease has been notified for
the last 48 hours. We wonder - should plague
have happily died out by the summer - what
pretext will be found byt he Ottoman author-
ities for the imposition of quarantine on
arrivals from Egypt, and notably at the Syrian,
ports.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions supressed by our correspondents, but we wish in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-few discussion.

div.head:
THE LEBANON.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,-- Io "L'Orient" of the 6th inst. the public has been made to under tand the true state of affairs in Mt. Lebanon, which has been misrepresented as being in perfect anáreby and tarmoil by some newspaper which has repted its columns to the enemies of H.E. Muzaffer Pasha for a period which expires when the Governor General of Lebanon is appointed for the next five years.
But in "L'Orient" of the 8th inst. a correspondent has ate opted to confirm the false piotare referred to by giving fresh addition to the false recital of everts narrated by the paper.
Thinking it useless to prove the falsehood of every story narrated by the discouter ted, I have taken at different intervale, some parts of...

He asks: It H.E. Mozeff yr Pasba is jast, wby did he imprison different sheikhs of Djazzia for pot acting according to his instructions in choosing member of the administrative council ! Ha imprisoned them because they deceive in the election and they bave been all bribed. Besides, what kind of a man did they choose ?

2. Why does he require the natives of Deir el Ksmsr to pay a special tax for making a road unknown to anybody! He did not requires special tax but many other villagers proposed to pay taxes for the construction of a very usefal road, nor is it his will to raise the questions of rcade. It pertails to the council.

3. Why did he imprison many notable Droses for not complying with hie de ire ? This is not trae; he did not imprison notable Droses for not complying with his desires; the di contented and dismissed kaimakam is the inventor of this accusation."

4. Why did Habib Pa ba el Sud, the chief of the Administrative Council, resigol Heda not resign, but was dismissed for not having the qualifications of a chiet to that council, H.E. Naoum Pasbs, the previous Governor Goveral of Lela son, will give necessary information abont bim and the honourable members of the Syrian commercial body in Cairo as well as in Syria koow better then the correspondent about his Excellency.
He goes on to prove the injustice and misgovernment of his Excellenoy, by saying that old and experienced men are not to be seen among his retinae ; it is only composed of young men.

HE Muzaffer Pasha has chosen vigorous and energetio young men, strong and capable to act in removing tremendous obstacles to the progress of the country, and has refused the "old and experienced" wbo are only experienced in ruining the country and promoting the interests of self-h members of the clergy, old mnen wbo, advancing in age, bave regeded from virtae, 1 his choice does but increase the confidenes in his wisdom and sogment his merited esteem.

As to the clergy of Lebanon, it can not be conceived how saob an unproductive class whose superiority and influence are founded on & pell apon the people ; who hold more than one balf of the land who; are ever seeking after political influence; who do nothing and enjoy machit cannot be conceived how these parasites can be of any ose to the Lebanon.
It is not necessary to prove what grest injary they are doing to that country and what great bindrance to its progress they are. History is ready to show it.

div.head:
ROYALTY AT PORT SAID.
ARRIVAL OF DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Wednesday.
The Duke and Dacbess of Connaught arrived bere ýesterilay on the P. and 0. steamer Marmora. The Doke is bound for Ceylon and Hong Kong, and will spend a few days in Egypt on his retarn.

Their Royal Highneses were welcomed by Mr. D. A. Cameron, HB.M.'s. Consol General, Mohamed Moubeb Pasho, Governor of the Canal, accompanied by Miralai Thomas Shalek Bey, Commandant of Police, and M. Dumont, on behalf of the Spez Canal Company. The Royal party landed on the company's wharf, and proceeded to the residence of the company, where they spent the night.
A picket of police under the orders of Saghcolaghaesi Moore, rendered military honours.

The Italian cruiser Calabria also arrived here yesterday with HR. H. the Duke of Udina on board. The two Dukes exchanged visits this morning. The Marmora fl-w the Royal Standard. The Duke ot. Connaught received several officials on his arrival.
The Italian Cruiser Calabria coaled this morning.. The Duke of Udina bad lanch at the Eastern Exchange.
Rain has fallen since early yesterday morning and shows no signs of abating.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p:
A telegram from Constantinple states that
arrivals in Turkish ports from the litteral ex-
tending from Lith to Et Wedl are subjected
to five days quarantine, disinfection, and de-
ratisation. The measures applied to arrivals
from Suez, Koussier, and Suakin have been
removed.

Arrivals from the litteral between Lith and
El Wedj are also subjected to the usual
quarantine restrictions in Egyptian ports.

div.head: DIVORCE OF A PRINCESS.
div.p: Princess Kamel Pasha Fadel, says "Al Moayad," has divorced his wife, Princess Fatimeh Hanem Efendi, whom he married last year. The lady is the widow of the late Mopshawi Pasha, and has now lost her title of Princess. "The divorce," adds our contemporary, "is stated to have been due to some personal difference between the Prince and his wife, and not to financial reasons. We understand, however, that the latter was the real motive of the divorce."

div.head: THE OASES SURVEY.
div.p: The announcement that appeared in our columns yesterday, to the effect that the Egyptian Government bas decided to make a survey of the four Oases in the Libyan desert and to despatch an inspector and an Irrigation official there, show that the development of there important and hitherto neglected assets of Egypt are now receiving the serious attention of the Government.

Undoubtedly there is a great future for the - Oaser, and it should be evident from the series of articler, which wa recently published, on the moon session of the Corporation of Western Egypt, that they should ere long attain as great A degree of prosperity as was their lot in ancient times. The Oases afford a fine field for profitable development, which is entrapped by the existing social conditions prevailing in the Delta and the Nile Valley. The extraordinary rise in the value of land, the insatiable yearning of every native to invest in real estate, the growth of the popala. tion, and the necessity for increasing the cotton crop, will lead to a great deal of interest being taken in the Oaser, as soon as the line to Khargeb is complete, and their possibilities can be seen and estimated after a railway joner ey of only a few hours' duration. As Boon as local hospitalists are able to judge with th ir own eye of the capabilities of the land the position of the company will be very different, and people no longer believe that the agricultural and mineral resources of the Okres are mere phantoms of the imagination.

The survey, which, as we announced yester day, is to be undertaken by the Ministry of Finance, will be an ardaous tuek. It is impossible to estimate the amount of cultivable and in the 01889 with any approach to erotitude, but the following it approximately the knowa area of Goveroment land available for cultivation, from which the grants to the Corporation will be made :Khargeh Osie, 460,000 taddans; Dakhleh Osis, 27,00 feddans ; Gubari distriot, 42,000 fed dans ; Parafra Oasis, 50,000 feddans ; Bobsrieb Oasie, 50,0 o foddans; total, 629,000 fe dans (652,000 acres).

There has up to now been only a geological survey of the Western Oases, wherein the question of the cultivable land was never touched upon, and the above figures are really only guesses as the system of taxót on is based on the wells and not on the land. Consequently the role prevailing elsewhere in Egypt that the rights of ownership over real property lapse when the land tax has not been paid during a certain period does not hold good bere. In many distripte, owing to the depopulation of the cases, large tracts of land have gone out of cultivation within recent times. Owing to the enormous possibilities of development in the OARDS forming part of the concession of the Curportion of W s'era Egypt, and the approaching completion of the railway to the Great Oasi", the time was ripe for a survey to bol made, and the Beyptian Government is to be congratulated on buying decided to take the matter in band forth with.

div.head: EGYPTS GOLD IMPORTS.
THE TOTALS FOR 1906
div.p: The total amount of specie imported into Egypt during the past year amounted to LB 9,077,402, as against L.B. 4,782,215 in 1905. These figures show that specie arrived here last year to the value of LE 4,295,187 more than in 1905, an increase of over four and a quarter millions in twelve months. These figures are more significant when it is considered that the total exports of specie from Egypt last year only amounted to LE 2,067,706, as against LE. 3,869,939 in 1906, & decrease in the amount of gold exported of LE. 1,802,233. In other words, Egypt received over four and a qqarter millions more gold last year than in the year before and exported nearly two millions less.

The total specie received from England in 1906 amounted to L.E. 5,949,720 in value, as against L.B. 1,471,813 for the previous year, a surplus of L.B. 4 477,907. The specie exported to Eogland was very small, only reaching total of L.B. 569,124, or L.B. 1,282,988 le=8 than in 1905, when this country sent LB. 1,852.112 to England.

In 1905 India sent specie to Egypt to the value of L.E. 1,462,509, botdid not export any during the past year. The exports of gold to Iodis in 1906 only amonpted to L.R. 120,907, as against L.B. 1,442,941 in 1905.
Turkey sent gold to the value of L.B. 1,451,443 in 1966, an increase of L.E. 795,159 in 1905. Egypt's exports of gold to Turkey amounted to L.B. 907,504, an increase of LR. 355,396 on 1905.
Specie to the value of L.B. 1,099,632 was received from France, an increase of L.E. 810,*95 on the figures for the previous year.. | The figures for the other countries are all under half a million.
DECEMBER'S STATISTICS.

The total number of English sovereigns which arrived in Egypt last December from England was of the value of L.B. 982,220. Engli-h sovereigns were imported from the following countries during December in the proportions given: Torkey, L.E. 287,071; Prance, L.E. 152 100; Austria, L.E. 25,477 ; Italy. L.E. 8,585; Greece, L.E. 1,173. The total amount of English sovereigns which arrived here last month reached the value of LE. 11.515.659. The imports of tbe corresponding month last year oply totalled the insignificant sam of L.B. 83,616.
The total of Napoleons imported last month amounted to L.E. 20,829. | Eogland sent Egyptian silver newly minted to the value of L.E. 13,930 last month.
The exports of specie in December amounted to only L.E. 40,714, as against L.E. 281,798 in the previous December. Tbe total exports consisted almost exclusively of English sovereigne, L.E. 40,281.

div.head: THE NEW EGYPTIAN GARRISON
div.p: The Army Coagoil has decided to convert the temporary appointment of Assistant Adjatant General at Cairo into & permanent appointment so long as the Bryptian Garrison remains at its present strength.

The increased staff will, therefore, consist of a major general, an side-de-champ, a major of the General Staff, an assistant adjutant general for administration, a D.A.A. and Q M.G., an 0.C. Royal Artillery, C.RE, 0.C. Army Service Corp, principal medical officers, senior veterinary officer, ohief ordnance Office, and distriot paymaster. Major-Gen. G.M. Ballook hold, the command in its increased status, and the temporary assistant adjutant-general is Colonel G. J. Cuthbert. The new force in Egypt comprises the 6th Drageour, Mounted Tofantry Detachment, Military Mounted Police, V. Battery R.H.A., No. 2 Company R.G.A, 2nd Company R.B. 3rd Coldstream Guard 18t Lanoasbire Poniliers, 1st K.OS.B, 2nd Royal Fadirkilling Fasiliere, 2nd Royal Berka Regiment, lat Royal Dublin Posiliers, « wing of the lat K.RRO, No. 71 Company A.8.0., No. 83 Company R.AM.C, No. 7 Company A.0.C., and Veterinary Detachment.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
SITUATION OF THE COMPANY.
div.p: (FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

The annual ordinary meeting of the Egyptian Cotton Mille will be held in London to-day, in order to receive and pass the stooopts for the financial year ended on the 30th September, 1906. We have received the report of the directors, and on looking through the accounts we remark that the results of the year's work. ing are far from being satisfactory, sbowing, as they do, a loss of £930, which, added to that acogmulated op to now and amounting to | £19,738, makes a total loss of £20,668, which is equal to more than one-eighth of the capital of the company. The Profit and Loss account shows the following figures on the 30th Sep tember 1906:
RECEIPTS.
EXPENSES.

row.cell:
Insurance, Taxes, and other expenses
at Cairo

Interest paid on debit balances to
Banks, and on Mortgages

div.p: It does not seem permissible that such heavy expenses as those of the Loodon board of the company sbould be maintained, when the actual situation of the company is 80 unsatisfactory and jastifies no management other than that of the local board. On the other hand, interest paid to the banks on debit balances and on mortgage loans seems to us to fetter heavily the improvement of the future prospects of the company, whose industrial receipts do not exceed £9,500 per annom.

We most recognize, however, that the com pády's business appears to be in a better condition than formerly. If the company could reduce its administrative expenses, it wonld perhaps be possible for it to gradually liquidate its debts, as well as its losses. The balance sheet of the ocmpany on the 30th September last sums up thus:

row.cell:
£50,000 of which issued (inclu-
ding interest due.... .. .

Sundry creditors on account of the
building of the factories (includ-
ing inerest due)............

div.p: It is extremely difficult to say it an improvement of the enterprise is to be hoped for. Ita debenture loan is so important, compared with its industrial receipt, that we, and most competent persons we have interviewed on the subject, are of opinion that a very great effort is needed in order to save it from almost inevitable ruin. If the company were to make another issue of shares, reducing its capital from £160.000 to, ay, £40,000, aod creating | 160.000 new bares of five shillings each, its 08:e would be considered from another point of view. The new share capital would have for object to pay off the various debts of the company, on which the latter pays annually interest exceeding £1,500, and this som would be acquired by the company. It is surely a measure which would prevent the company from incurring losses in the fatore, and which would perhaps improve its present prospects. In any case, the board of directors ought, in the interests of the shareholders, to reduce the capital of the company, its asset being now absolutely fictitious.
We submit the above sobe me to the parties interested, and hope to see our recommendations carried out in the near future.

div.head:
MR. ROBERTSON, M.P..
MORE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: Mr. Robertson's visit continues to aronse considerable interest in the local Press. His recent peregrinations in the provincer have especially attracted the attention of the native and foreign newspapers, and any and various comments are being passed on the visit of the Radical Member for the Tyneside division of Northumberland to the scene of the tragedy of Depishwai.

"Al Zaber," a Moslem daily newspaper of Cairo, pablisbes a leading article on Mr, Robertson to the following effect :-Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P, who after the Denishwai affair gave vent to some severe criticisms in the House of Commons upon the jadgment passed by the specially constituted coort in that case, is, an enthusiaetio Liberal and recently came to Egypt on a vieit. Here he was met by some enthusiastio members of the Nationalist Party, who labour ander the impression that he entirely sbares their political views. Bat the truth is that there is no real | accord between Mr. Robertson and them, except that both are zeslots. Mr. Robertson is a member of a British political party, the members of which believe that their policy is based on right principles and should be followed in the interests of their pation. Can any of our zealous Nationalists bring forward evidence to prove that their policy is based on similarly bigbminded aims ? When Mr. Robert on arrived in Cairo people went to greet him and exposed to him their opinions. Various were the romours broited abroad as to the objects of his visit and doubtless he is quite ignorant of many of these reports. Many natives who have heard all abçat Mr. R sbertson's visit to the natives of Depishwai are now led thereby to believe in the emancipation of Egypt through his instrumentality, but if they had read what was published io the "Times" they would not be so bopeful. This gentleman is really among the strongest supporters of Eng. lisb poliay in Egypt, for all Englishmen desire to see their Egyptian policy to be firmly establisbed, and because some of them want to see whether there is anything to criticise in it, their action is merely due to a desire to improve their country's policy here. Under such circumstances therefore it is sheer nonsense to expect that some of the Erglish will help the Egyptians to get rid of the Occupation. Under the circomstances all that can be done is to co-operate with the English by coming to a good understanding with them in matters which can benefit Egypt hereafter. The overwhelming po ioy some of us Egyptians adopt will only produce the worst effects as we have already seen in some cases. We hope that Mr. Robertson's personal intercourse with some of the Nationalists will lead to these persons moderating their views and teach tbem to act in a befitting manner so that they may not mislead the whole nation.

div.head: NEW BREWING COMPANY.
div.p: A Khedivial decree has been issued author-ising the formation of a new company at | Alexandria entitled the Société Anonyme de Brasserie et Rzérie." The capital is LE 60,00). in 15,000 shares of L.E. 4 each. The board of directors is composed of Messrs. Walter Bomonti, Adolpbe Bomonti, Paul Hahnloser, and Hepri Zboer.

The objects of the company are officially stated to be as follows :-L Société aura pour ohjet l'acquisition, la création et l'exploitation op Eżypte des désort queries de riz, de fabriques de bière et de glace et d'autres industries similaires.

div.head: LAND INVESTING & BUILDING
div.p: We would draw the attention of those of our readers seeking profitable investments to the prospectus, which we pobliebed yesterday, of the Bgyptian Land Investment and Building Company, Limi' ed, which has been formed with a capital of £300,000, divided into | 298,000 Ordinary shares of £1 and 40.000 Deferred shares of 1s. eacb, for the purpose of acquiring and developing land, industrial and other undertakings in Egypt, the Sudan and elsewhere, including the securing of land conoesrious and the development of building estates. The board of directors propose to direct their attention more particularly to the purchase and development of building land and its division into plots and their subsequent leasing or re-sale. Amongst other remunerative methods of dealing with properties which may be acquired is the erection of bones and other buildings and the re-sale of them on the instalment system. As is wall kons, the demand for residential premises in the principal, towns of Egypt is far in excess of the supply, and the directors propose to take up business of the foregoing nature and anticipate * considerable demand from purebasers on the instalment system and otherwise. Indeed, we anticipate that in this branch of the business the company is sure to meet with a considerable amount of success, in view of the fact that rentals have been going on during the last few years at an abnormal rate, and. there does not seem to be any immediate prospect of abatement. The issue of the company's capital promises to be covered several times. Prospectuses may be obtained on application to any of the following agencies:Comptoir Pinapoier sed Commercial d'Bgypte, Avastassiou Jabalé and C, Arditi and Co. J. and G. Bekyt and Co., Cambo Maximo Lombardo and Co.

The "Times" gives the following biographical sketch of the father of the Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality, whose death we announced last week - The Rev. James Chataway graduated in 1851 from Clare College, Cambridge, and was ordained deacon in 1852 and priest in 1853 by Dr. Pepy, Bishop of Worcester. In 1856 be was nominated to the viosrage of Wartliog, near Hastings, which be resigned ten years later, accepting the corsey of Heckfield, Hants. In 1870 Dr. Harold Browne, Bisbop of Winchester, appointed him to the rectory of Rotherwiek, Dear Winchfield, where his incomber cy lasted for 25 years. After his resignation in 1895 he made frequent journeys round the world, visiting his seven sons, of whom three were established in Aus tralis, two in Canada, one in South Africa, and one in Egypt. One of his daughters is married to Mr. Moberly Bell and another to Mr.T. P. O. Haddleston, sensor of non colle. riate students at Cambridge. One ron, the Hoo. Vincent Chataway, was Minister of Agriculture in Queensland, and another was a prominent legislator in the same colony.

div.head:
JAMAICA EARTHQUAKE.
KINGSTON IN FLAMES.
TALE OF KILLED AND INJURED.

div.p:
The earthquake in Kingston occurred on
Monday afternoon. The news, which is meagre
and conflicting, emanates from Holland Bay,
via St. Thomas Island

Mr. Hamar Greenwood, M.P., cabling to the
Colonial Office, states that the oity has been
entirely destroyed. Sir James Pergusson, ex-
Minister, is reported dead.

The Governor, who is directing affairs, is
assisted by Sir Alfred Jones. Later reports
indicate that the death-roll will not exceed 100
persons. An outbreak of fire succeeded the
earthquake bat is apparently confined to a
small section of the city.

The work of fighting the fismes was pursued
vigorously throughout yesterday. The prin-
cipal hotel and other important buildings have
been destroyed, but otherwise the fire bas been
confined to the docks. The number of the
injored is estimated at several bandreds.
The hospitals are filled. (Reuter)

An official despatch, undated, confirms the
news of the severe earthquake at Kingston on
Monday afternoon, which was followed by a
fire, which, however, has been confioed to-day
to the portion of the town where the wharves,
warehouses, and camp hospital are. There lat-
ter bave been destroyed. 80 persons have been
killed. Major Hardyman has been seriously in-
jored. The general hospital is crowded with 300
injured. The fires are decreasing. The Myrtle-
bank hotel and cable offices have been destroyed.

With the exception of Sir James Fergusson,
who is missing, it is believed that the cotton
delegates are safely on board a steamer. The
numbers of the killed and wounded are still
uncertain. Slight shocks continue to be felt.

The Royal Mail Company announces that
Mr. Constantine, their superintendent, has
been killed, as well as Captain Young, of the
S.S. Arno.

The Admiralty have ordered the cruisers
Brilliant and Indefatigable to proceed to
Kingston. The American Admiral is also going
there.
Later.

Forty soldiers have been killed in the camp
hospital. The fire started, along the wharver,
where the wreckage of the freight sbed offered
immediate fae!, slogging the streets, and caus-
ing indescribable confusion and panic. The
flames along the waterfront made considerable
headway before effective work was started.

The Colonial Bank has been destroyed but
the vaults and the books are safe.
Later.

Almost every house in the city has been
destroyed by the dire which broke out after
the earthquake.

The business section is a heap of smoulering
ashes.

Four hundred persons have been killed and
a thousand injured.

A number of prominent merchants and
professional men have been killed. Fort-five
invalid soldiers have perished in the military
hospital. (Reuter)

An earthquake is reported from Jamaica,
which has partially destroyed the town of
Kingston. Hundreds of people have been killed
and thousands injured. Some telegrams atte-
nuate the disaster. (Havas)

The islands Leyte and Samar were swept by
a typhoon on the 10th instant. There are no
details. (Reuter.)

Three more fatal cases of plague have occur-
red here. (Havas)

The Episcopate has assembled to consider a
general policy and to advise the Pope of their
views.

M. Briand announced in the Chamber yes-
terday evening that the pension allowances to
aged priests would be continued. (Reuter)

Mr. Haldance has formally given notion of his
dissent to the Channel Tunnel Bill. (Reuter)

The bureau of manu-
factures is in possesion of the following sam-
ples of cotton goods from Egypt: Italian and
Mauchister brown and white calicoes, native
manufactured and Manchester printed c-liser,
Egyptian raw cotton of various grades, fez
hats, tarbonobe, a cap worn inside of the tur-
bap. These samples were collected for the be-
nefit of American manufacturers, and the
bureau is anxious to place them in their
hands. They will be sent upon application
to manufacturers, chambers of commerce and
other commeroial organizations located in cot-
ton manufacturing centres.

div.head: ON SYRIAN SOIL*
div.p:
Beauty of style in description and beauty of
colour in illustration are the two conspicuous
features of this work. Mrs. Inchbold is a
patient and faithfal observer, and she has a
vivid yet delicate pen; the result is that she
has so unfolded before us the scenes that she
witnessed in har travels through Syria, and so
described the impressions made upon her by
her romantio experiences, that even the most
soulless reader feels a spiritual uplifti
is attuned to the brooding spirit of the East.
The cedars of Lebanon, the vine olad hills, the
groves of oranges, and of olives, are limped
with a skilful pen; but more impressive than
these are the people themselves, the Droses and
the Maronites-yver suspicious of one another
-the goatherds of Galilee, the Jews of Tiberias
and Jerusalem, and the pilgrims from Moslem
and Christian countries who swarm in the Holy
City at Eastertide. All these are drawn for us
in a picturesque yet sympathetic manner,
whilst the scenes in which these varied peoples
move and have their being are depicted for us
by Mr. Stanley Inchold with all the richness
of colour and the romantic glow of the East.

The chapters on the Lebanon are full of
curious interest, and enable us to realize the
customs, costumes, and creads of the conser-
vative Druses. We see the children learning
their lessons at school ani the villagers follow-
ing their peaceful parsuits; we are introduced
to such contrasted scenes as a marriage, a
funeral, and the festive celebration of the
English Consul's birthday. The admiration for
the English felt by the Droses is indeed remark
able. At the time when the author was in
Syria the South African war was taking place,
and the Droses asked anxioasly after its
progress, and expressed their readiness to
march at once to the assistance of the English
troops at the slightest biot from the English
Sovereign. The religion of the Drages, which
had remained a myatery to Europeans for
eight hundred years, is still somewhat obscure
despite the knowledge gleaned from some
sacred books once stolen by soldiers from
Hasbeys, at the foot of Mount Hormon. The
people regard themselves as Unitarians; their
chief doctrine is the transmigration of souls;
and they believe that the population is always
the same, as the soal of a dying person imme-
iately enters the body of a child about to be
born.

div.head: REINCARNATION.
div.p:
A sidelight upon this doctrine was afforded
by the death of a venerable sheikh at the age
of 110, whose barial, with the accompanying
lamentation by wailing women, is described
very graphically:

He had been a wise sheikh, a good sheikh.
He would therefore be born again in China.

"How blessed will it be when all people
are born again in China," ch snted the
women, as we stood there, the belief of the
simple minded of their race being that the
soul of a good Drose is always boro again
in China, that of a bad Druse in Egypt. In
a word, China is their ideal Paradisa, Egypt
their place of torment. They hold to the
firm conviction that bali of the Chinese of
the present day bs ve been Droses in their
past lives.

In every housebold of the Droses there is a
snow white, well-fed lomb tothered in the
court, which is diligently fed with mulberry
leaves and wate:ed and wasbed at the spring.
At the fall of autumn the sheep, already too
unwieldy to walk, are carried to the slaughter
for the sostenance of human Ime in the
bleak winters of the highland villages." The
dissected animal is preserved with salt and
spices in large jers, and covered over with
supply of fat from the tail, and the jars are
then sealed for winter use.

Between the Drase: god the Maronites-
"their bereditary toes in matters religious,
political, and social"--thøre still exists an
intermittent foud. The Maronites of the
Lebanon are more nacerous than the Druses,
and are equally bold and martial. Their sect
was founded in the sixth ceutory, and ten
centuries later they became subject to the
ecclesiastical jurisdiction of Rime. Ever singe
1860, when a fierce outbreak against the
Christians of Damascus took place, a feeling
of distrust and bostility has prevailed between
the two neighbouring races of the Lebanon.

More than once when we were in the
Lebanon, the news spread up to the moun-tains of a sudden quarrel in the native quar-
ters of Beyrout, resulting in the murder of a
Christian by a Druse. Immediately the
whole district would be on the alert, for the
aggressor would at once fly to the bills, and
Lebanon soldiers be sent ont to trap him in
every direction. DSecret meetings of Druses
and Maronites would be held in the dead
of night, weapons brought surreptitiously
into the village, precaution and count-
precautions discussed by both communities
alike.

A mere mention must suffice of the pictu-
re que, and occasionallly poetic, account of the
Temple ruins of Baelbek, the synanogue of
Tiberias, the moonlight effect on the Sea of
Galilea, the busy scene of the port of Jaffa,
and the motley through of cosmopolitan pilgrams
in the Holy city of Jerusalem.

"Under the Syrian Sun." By A.C. Inchbold, With
forty full-page coloured plates and eight black and
white drawings by Stalney Inchbold. London: Hutchin-
son and Co. Two vols. 24s. net.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: London, January 11.

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p:
The easing of the money market is farther
disclosed, and a continued tendency in this
direction for some little time is expected. It
would be difficult, however, to give any as-
surance that this state of things will continue
long into the New Year, as large demands are
sure to be made upon the pablic in the early
spring. It is to be hoped the Bank of England
directors will not lend ear to the clamour for
the reduction of the Bsok rate at the present.
Apart from a merely fractional rise in the
Berlin cheque, the foreign exchanges remain
adverse to this country, and the New York
cable transfer rate has receded forther. It is
also noticeable that America is still endeavour-
ing to borrow largely in this market.

Yesterday's Bauk return was better than
was expected. The sum of £1,729,969 was
added to the reserve, making a total of
£21,418,555, and this together with a dimina-
tion in the liabilities ososed & rise in the
"Proportion" of 6.47 per csot. to 39.97. Cash
has returned freely from internal circulation,
as, notwithstanding shot efflux of gold for
abroad of £54,000, the stock of coin and
bullion is larger by £1,371,154. There was
a contraction of £358,815 in the active note
circulation. Compared with last year the re-
serve shows an increase of £2,602 567.

Yesterday fonds found ready employment
at 34 to 84 per cent. from day to day, and for
a week the charge was 3-4 per cent.

div.head: The Stock Exchange.
div.p:
While the vol me of business on the Stock
Exchange is not such as to cause enthasiasm
among members of that institution, the tone
continues to exbibit the improvement which
has been noticeable since the commenc-ment
of the year. Allowing for the uncertainty of
the future of money, there is little cause for
complaint. Nowithstanding the fact that the
Bank's reserve is now over a million higher
than it was twelve months ago, when the rate
was only 4 per cent, there is still much sus-
picion as to what will happen during the next
few months, and this necessarily exercises
restrictiog effect opon investment braidess.

One section of the "House," however, is
abilant, and it is the mining section. After
the years of depression and gloom which
have overshadowed this market, and the tre-
mendous losses it has sustaine, the very
substantial revival whieb has taken place this
week comes as a God sond. The splendid re-
turns of the gold output of the Bank have
promptly impressed investors, and we should
not be in the least surprised it the present
upward movement is but the beginning of a
period of great activity for the shares. To-
day markers have been quiet in view of the
settlement.

div.head: Consols.
div.p:
The release of a large amount of dividend
and interest money, and anticipations of
an early reduction in the Bank rate, brought
some fairly considerable buying orders to
Consols at the beginning of the week, but
these have since declined, and for the grester
part of the week tbe market bae been doll.
Consols leave off to night at 8618 for cash
and 8 1/2 for the account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p:
The publication of the preliminary figure
regarding the forthcoming Japanese Badget,
and the satisfactory statements as to the
trade of the country, started a revival in
Japanese stock, which contioned much in
evidence until yesterday. The Fours on Wed-
nesday rose from 1 to 11. and there were
gains in the 4 per cents, of abont to 7/16.

Yesterday the Fives of 19012 and the Fours and the Second
Series Fours an 1 the Sscond
44 por cent were 1/8 higher.

This return of interest in the bonds most
be very gratifying to the financial advisere
of the Japanese Gvernment, and it is safe
to assume that immediately there is an easing
of the monetary sitaation, the new £25,000,000
Four per cent. loan, which is to be used for
the conversion of the 6 per cent. bonde, will
be launched.

Japanese issues have been rather offered
to-day, and there are losses of 1/8 to 1/4.

Russians have been dull, and the serip of
the Fives has relapsed to 45 discount. The
Fours are quoted 774.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p:
The one topic of interest in the home railway
market has been the transter by the White
Star Line from Liverpool to Southampton of
their Wednesday Atlantio service of steamers.
The probable effect of this and other secessions
from th Mersey port, which are expected to
follow, opon the London & North Western
Railway, huye dataraMy caused come anxiety
among the more nervous holders
of the stock of the premier railway, but, apart from a slight
decline after the anpondcement, the quotation
has kept steady, the fact being, of course, that
the shares are too well held to be easily
affacted. Yesterday the quotation recovered 1/2 to
152 3/4, and the close to night is 153, as compar-
ed with 1531 last Friday.

The announcement of the London & South
Western's 81ccess in pergoading the White
Star line to transfer their boste to Southamp-
ton was hailed with delight by their sharehold-
ers, inasmuch as the company as proprietors
of the docks at the son bern port stand to gain
in a two-fold wense by the move. The opera-
tions of a bear clique have, bowever, re rotel
the upward movement of the sbaren. The
Deferred close to night at 53), showing a slight-
loss on the werk. The Ordioary are 156, which
shown no changes on last Friday's close.

div.head: Americans.
div.p:
Dealings in the American market have been
restricted. Wall Street is alarmed at the de-
velopments arising out of the Horriman railway
enquiry, and it is feared that the attitude of the Government at present bodes no good for
railway enterprise in the States.

Yesterday the tone was rather more confident,
but the market was quiet, though movements
were generally in favoor of holders. Milwankee
recovered 24 to 158, Unions advanced to
1851, United States Steel Corporation and
the Preference :

The market has been weak to-day. Pennsyl-
vania, and Canadian Pacifics bave relapsed
27, and Baltimore and Ohio 2.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p:
The Egyptian market, after the temporary
idlenens resulting from the disorganisation
caused by the extended Christmas holidays in
Egypt, has now recovered some of the activity
which characterised December dealing and
the good business done doring the past few
days sagors well for the succes of these shares
in the anconeding months.

Cariously enough, the new land company
United Bzyptian Lande, have provided the
feature of the week. The shares have been in
great request, and at one time were at goo l
as premium. The bnoyancy of the Deferred
shares caused some little excitement, the price
being rushed up to 11%, bat they left off
down at 107. The closing quotations to-night
are, Ord. premium. Deferred, 10.

The new issuee of the Corporation of Western
Egypt is not particularly favourable to holders
of the present wherer, and of course the price
is slightly essier at 1 1. At the same time,
the project is looked upon very favourably,
as it appears to have gone further than the
experimental stage, and is likely to turn out
vary profitably. The shares of the new issue
are quoted | premium, but there do not
appear to be many dealings at this price, as
most of the subscribers are expecting to get
what they apply for at par. We understand
that about half the amount has been taken in
each country, and we do not doubt the success
of the issue.

Egyptian Estates remain firm at 2 ½. and
the Deferred at 21-23. National Bank of Egypt
have been up to 28% but clone 281. Agricul.
tural Bat k also are easier at 9H, after being
94. The Dabentares are dowo again at 89).
Land Bank are up to 9, and Land and General
Trust have been enquired for at 5/3 premiom.
Daira Banieh clige 178, and th Deferred at
98-100. There is no change in Union Ponciere
at 67, Egyptian Markets at 1), and Salt and
Soda at 1d. Bark of Abyssinia are better at
¾ discount. Delta Preference are quoted nomin-
ally 12, and Delta Land and Investment 4 ½.

div.head: Mining.
div.p:
A very satisfactory tone has been prevalent
in the mining market throughcut the wack,
and there has been generally a broadening of
business, which has been considerably belped
by orders from Paris. It is recognised that as 1
yet the professional element is dominant, but
there are already gratifying signs of returning
confidence in mining shares on the part of
the investing public. This confidence cannot
fail to be considerably strengthened by
the figures jost published of the Band
output for the mouth of December and the
complete returns for the whole of 1996.
During December the outpat amounted to no
less than 550,167 Ounce, valued at £2,436,961,
which shows an increase on November of
16,793 or £71,236. The total for the year 1906
is 5,786,617 ounces, valued at £24,579,987, as
against 4,997, 221 ounce, or £20,802,074, in
1905. These figures are very satisfactory, and
the highly prosperous state of the mining
industry thus revealed only serves to throw
into greater contrast the present reduced
value of many of the sbares. With the prospect
of an early settlement of the country, a very
considerable appreciation in the stocks of all
the companies must follow as a matter of
course.

This week Modderfontein have been a
good point. Yesterday tha shares advanced
5/16 to 7 1/8. which compared with 67 last
Friday, and Raud Mines moved up 7/32 to
7 5/16. showing a gain on the week of 11/32.
Goldfields were 7/32 higher at 4 27/32.

Koffice have agaia received considerable
support to-day, sad farther advances are
general.

It gives us satisfaction to be able to re-
cord an apward movement in some of the
Egyptian mining share', which have been
flat for so long. Yesterday there was a good
demand for Nile Va'l ye, and the price
spurted 2/6 to 68. Egyptian Mines also were
favoured, and advanced 91. to 4/8. To nigb Nile
Valley, close at 6. and Egyptian Mine
at 4/9. With the increasing ac'ivity of South
African shares, we may confidently expect
that much more attentio will be given to
the Egyptian section

div.head:
Drifting Into Decline
From Sheer Bloodlessness.
A Girl's Startling Tale.
Dreadful Fatigue and Backache.
Weak and Thin as a Skeleton.
Cured when Hope was Lost.
Her Blood Supply renewed by
DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.
div.p:
The pangs and miseries of Armenia, that
scourge of woman's life, are needlessly borne,
year in and year out, by thousands of the
weaker sex from girls in their tender terms to
woman to full age. The following history of
Miss Emmire R. Williams, living at Bridge
Road, Bentball, Broseley, Salop, is given as
proof of the fact that by actually making New
Good Blood Dr. Williams' Pink Pills restore
brightness, health and energy to suffering
Academics.

"My life was once at so low an ebb through
bloodlessness," said Miss Williams, "that I
feared that at any time I might swoon and
die-in fact, my mind was always brooding
upon the thought of the early death to which
I was daily drifting.

"My illness began with dreadful fatigue in
addition to a dull backache. I lost my colour,
and became very thin, but even then I failed
to realise that I was suffering from anemia.
My lips and gums were white, and I had
distressing palpitations.

Hating with a mere pretenes,
I had positively no appetite; indeed
the many medicines I had taken weakened my
stomach. I lost weight so that my appearances
was quite startling. It was a labour to climb a
few stairs for every step seemed to,
Tear the Strength out of me,
and I had to stop frequently to regain my
breath."

"That is true" said Mrs. Williams, "and
after a little walk my daughter would fall on
to the sofa in a state of collapses, unable to
speak a word."

"I was," continued Miss williams, "languid
all day and sleepy too, yet unable to sleep at
night. All through the night I was haunted
with dreadful nervous fears, and if I dosed off
some nightmare would arouse me again. Every
morning I arose with splitting headaches and
dragging weakness in my back. No one though
I would ever be well, and friends warned me
that I was in a deline. Thin as a skeleton and
pitiably weak, full of dull aches and tremours, I
sank daily worse and worse until I felt certain
that I was beyond recovery. When at last I
had been given up as an incurable, a friend
advised my mother to give me Dr. Williams'
Pink Pills for Pale People and soon afterwards
we read about curse
by these pills in cases
like mine. I had taken
so much medicine
that we were very
doubtful of success, but mother insisted upon
me trying these pills, so I commenced treat-
ment. The result was simply surpring. After
a while I greatly improvied in every way. I was
cheerful, and my lips and cheeks got back
some of their colour. I ate very well at meal
times without fear of indegestion or sickness,
and as I continued the pills, so my progress
became more apparent. Each dose brought
back strength with the new blood that was
made by the pills, and
My figure gre eerect
once more. I regained all my lost flesh and
became more energetic than I had ever been
sleeping well at night and fww from head-aches by day. My appetite and activity and
bright sprits have been well maintained ever
since then, and after only a few boxes of Dr.
Williams' Pink Pills I am well again."

For languishing, lifeless anemic girls and
woman there is no remedy equal to Dr. Wil-
liams Pink Pills for Pale People. They have
cured not only Anemia but Indegestion, Pal-
pitations, Rheumatism, Sciatics, Neuralgia,
St. Vitus Dances, Eczema, Nervous Disorders,
Paralysis, Locomotor Atary, and Effects of
Overwork or Worry, also ladies' Ailments.

div.head: NAVAL CONTRACTS.
div.p:
TENDERS are invited for new contracts
for the supply of fresh provisions and water to
His Britannio Majesty's Ships at Alexandria
for twelve months, from April 1st 1907.

Each article (viz, beef, mutton, vegetables,
bread and water) must be tendered for rep
rately, and tenders for all the articles offered
by any particular Firm must be entered on the
same form.

Forms for tenders may be obtained at the
British Consplate.

Sealed tenders in duplicate, made out on
these forms, will be received by H.B.M. Congol
General until noon on January 31st 1907.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL MAIL STEAMSHIP
AND GRAVING DOCK COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p:
NOTICE is hereby given that at the Annual
General Meeting of this Company held at
London on the 14 h December 1906, it was
decided to pay a dividend of 10 per cent. on
the Ordinary Shares for the year ending 30th
June 1906.

Holders of Share Warrants to Bearer will be
paid their dividend at the rate of 2/ per
share, less income tax, against presentation of
Coupon No. 4 on and of er the 31st December
1906, at the Imperial Ottoman Bank, Alex-
andria, or at Messrs. Glyn, Mille, Carrie and
Co., Lombard Street, London, B.C.

Registered holders of Ordinary Shares will
receive their Dividend Warranta by post. Alexandria, 17th December, 1906.

Ces dépôts pourront être versés au Service de la Comptabilité Générale, ayant l'heure fixée pour l'ouverture des enchères oa bien, en séance même, mais avant la mise en adjodiontion de obsque lot.

Il sera prooédé à la vente en commençant par les lots les plus obers, ce qui permettra aux enchérissenre, qui ne seront pas restés adjudicataires d'an lot, de poursuivre, s'ils le désirent, les snobère d'un autre lot, avec le même cantionnement.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: LA Délégation Manicipale s'est réunie le 15 janvier 1907 4 b. 1/2 p.m. sous la présidevos do 8. E. le Dr. Sshiess pacbs.
Présents: MM. Berechi, Yehia pacha, Baron do Mennsoe, Abani bey, Mansour bey, Dr. V. lensin, membres, W. P. Chstaway, administra. tear, I. Sedky bey, secrétaire géoéral.
La Délégation déaide les travaux de cans. lisation et de redresrement de la rue Imam Aly, sauf approbation des crédits par la Com. mission.

Elle accepte certains arrangements avec les concasiondaires des carrières d'Aton Zabel, en voe d'ane plus grande fourniture de cail. lange pendant nne période déterminée, ca ear. plus pouvant loi ere utile pour les travaux projeté, de confection de la route de la cor niebe.
La Délégation émet un avis favorable & divers excédents et emprises pour l'élargis redressement des voies évalue: par le Conseil d'Estimation dans gs séance da 5 janvier 19 7.
Elle charge les services de lai présenter un rapport sur les différentes off es présentée à la Dé égation pour la fornitare de 14,000 m.o de dalles.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Il y a eu ce matiu passablement d'activité et une reprise partielle. Les valeurs les plus échangées sont la Hooker, l'Uaited Lands, les Butate, le Comptoir et la Building Lands.
La Hooker, très domandée, s'é'ève à 1 11/32 aobetaars. L'action United s'inscrit à 19/32 et la part de fondateur à 10 livras acheteara.

L'Assemblée da Comptoir Financier, tenne hier dans l'après-midi au siège social, a accepté à l'unanimité l'augmentation da capital de 1/3 million a 1 million de livres, ainsi que la distribution d'un coupon intérimaire de 6% pour le 5 do moia prochaio. Très bien tenue, l'action monte à 8 8/16 l'ancienne et 7 13/16 la nouvel le. 'Lupart de fondateur, de son côté, béuéficie de 3 livres à 10% acbeteurs.
Les Estates s'avancent & 2 11/16 vendears et la Building Laods : 61/16.

Ea hausse également l'Agricole à 9 17/32, la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie à 924 1/2, les Dividendes Tram WAYS À 359 achatenra. l'Obli gation ancienne Crédit Foncier & 841 1/2, la Bapque d'Athènes à 137 1/2, la Deferred Delta 18 1/2, la Nile Land & 18 1/2, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail. 36/3 et l'Union Funcière 63/16, en très bonne tendance.

Par contre, la National Bank reonle à 27 7/8, 1. Behera à 41 1/2, les Nangovich Hotels à 99 1/8, les Dalta Land á 4 7/8 vendeurs, l'Iovestment À 1 3/8. Ia Land Investment 5 2/4 les Splendid Hotels & 4 1/16, et l'Allotment à 3 9/16.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans chaoge. ment.
La tendance est bien meilleure qu'hier, bra's pour que cette ané ioration de maintiat, il faudrait qu'on s'écar a: graduellement des valegra qui ont été trope pousséde sans aucun motif.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 16 Janvier 1907.

Le taux de l'escompta libre Londres & été encore réduit de 1/8 8 4 7/8 pour cent. An Stock Exobange, le Consolidé a de nouveau haussé de 1/8 à 87 1/1. L'Unifiée « baissé de 1/4 X 102 1/4. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 28 1/4. L'Agricole est restée invariée à 95,8, de même que la Daira & 17 3/4 et la Delta Light 19.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier regagné 5 franos à 783. La Banque d'Athènes n'est maiotande à 139. Len Lots toros ont avancé de 3 francs à 154. L'Enpront ruspe & passé de 87.9) à 88.80.

Au début de la ré-nce, notre marché des valeurs montré, ce matin, de l'animation, ainsi que de bonnes dispositions, anxquelles ont succédé le calme et une certaine faiblesse. Il y ou onasite une reprise sur presque toute la cote, mais de nombreuses réalisa tiops ont déterminé un mouvement de réaction qui s'est prolongé jusqu'à la clôture. .
Dans le compartiment der Banquer, la Na tional a été ramenée à 28 et l'Agr cole A 9 9/16 Ls Cassa di Sconto est remontée à 282 La Banque d'Athènes s'est raffermie à 136-137.

Le Crédit Poncier est resté à 779. L. Daira a faibli á 17 1/2, la Bébéra à 41 1/2-3/4 et la Nile Land à 17 3/4. L'immobilière a avancé à 380. L'Enterprise and Development est revenue à 13 3/4 et sa part 211/. L'Union Popoiere a progressé à 6 1/16 1/8. Les Allot ments ont fléobi à 3 7/16 pour finir à 3 1/2; leur part a baireé à 135.

Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont débuté en bonne tendance à LE 19 pour atteindre 191/4, résctionner à 18 1/2 et clotnTer à 17 1/4 mur quelques réalisatione. Leur part « avancé & P. E. 300 pour terminer à 285

L'Epargne Immobilière s'est tenue à 4 1/8: ea part est revenue à 3:16. L'Express Nile e, resté à 6 1/8; as part a avancé à 375. La part de fondateur Egyptian Mail a failbli a 5 5/9 Les parts de fondateur Societe Generale Egyptianenne ont regagne 1- frances a 114.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Care out avance e 295 frances. les ciments ont baisse a 61 et l'Anglo American Nile a 5 5/16.

Le groupe des valeurs hotelieres a ete monvemente. Les Nungovich ont progresse a 22 1/8 3/16. Les Egyptian out failbli a 12 ¾. Ebonne tenue, les Upper Egypt ont beneficie de ¼ a 4 7/8. Les Excelsior, qui ont ete l'objetd'un certain movement ont cloture a 4 1/4
et leur part à 15/8. Las Natio al ont é é ramenés • 3 15/16 4 ; leur part a atteint 105 pour réaotionner en obture 90.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont fini à 4 3/8 et les Abdy à 1 3/8. Les Butstes ont avancé à 2 9/16-5/8 et leur part à 21 3/8. Les Salt and Soda ont faibli & 24 sh., kis Markets à 29 sb. 41/2 et les New Egyptian à 31 sh. 10 1/2.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Cor poration des Agents de change du Caire, qui doit être tenue une fois par an dans le courant de Jaavier, vient, enfiu, d'ê re convoqués pour le Mercre ti 30 da courant, à 3 h. p.m.
Aux termes des Statuts (art. 7) les membres doivent en être informés par un simple avis qui leur sera adressé 15 jours à l'avance.
Or oette formalité a été remplie avant hier seulement, 14 Janvier 1907, par une lettrecirculaire signée par M. D. Lenos, secrétaire. Il était tempe...

L'ordre du joar comporte; les rapports du Comi'é; do trésorier et des consects : des "propositions diverses" et les élections prévues par les artieles 11 et 15 des Statuts, c'est-à-dire la réélection ou le remplacement du président, des membres du Comité et leurs suppléants.
Nous en reparlerons, des "propositions diverses" spécialement, qui, semble-t-il, seraient remarquablement intéressantes.

Os annonce officieusement la prochaine convooation d'ane assemblée extraordinaire de l'Eryptian Estates Co. en vue de loi faire ap. prouver l'émission de £2 000 000 d'obligations hypothécaires à placar à Londres, Paris et Bruxelles.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

The demand for Egyptian cotton on the Spot coatiuues very limited, prices being inragalar, and the quotations barely supported, but without change. Io Potores a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest values:

American Futures. The market this week bas experienced continual minor fluctuation, bat prices bsve generally had a slightly improving tendency, and to-day's values are 5 @ 8 points hizte- for old crop positions, but only 3 higher for new crops. Spinner hwe purchased freely, and reports from Manchester confirm a large business again for India and China; as regards speculation th:10 is practically nothing doing, nor can much be exrectes whilst the movemeuts of the crop continue on such a large scale.
The Bureau Census Ginners Report published yesterday in New York is in accordanca with general expectation, and does not throw any new light apon the position, which is unusually puzzling.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
